channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Case Against Australian Billionaire Could Put A Hitch in His Swagger
item.description: A Chinese company claims that Clive Palmer, the Australian mining magnate, used money intended for an iron ore port on his political party instead.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Afghan Presidential Contenders Say They Will Reverse Expulsion of Times Reporter
item.description: The rival candidates, who are deadlocked over the results of a June election, said they would welcome the return of the Times reporter, Matthew Rosenberg.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and REBECCA CORBETT

item.title: Palestinians Suspected of Collaborating With Israel Are Executed in Gaza Strip
item.description: Witnesses said over a dozen were killed as recent Israeli attacks on Hamas leaders most likely led the militants to send a harsh public message to potential informants.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Hamas militants prepared to execute a person suspected of collaborating with Israel on Friday in Gaza City.

item.title: Lens Blog: Afropunks, Come as You Are
item.description: Phil Knott’s portraits of the Afropunk scene show “the other black experience” among fans of alternative music.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By WHITNEY RICHARDSON

item.title: Film About Indira Gandhi’s Assassination Is Barred From Indian Theaters
item.description: Critics said the film, “Kaum De Heere,” depicted the men who killed the prime minister in 1984 in a favorable or even romanticized light.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Death Row Inmate Acquitted After 8-Year Ordeal
item.description: Nian Bin was sentenced to death four times, convicted of fatally poisoning two children in eastern China. Each time, he appealed and a higher court ordered another hearing. Then on Friday, judges declared Mr. Nian not guilty and freed him from death row.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Women’s Photo Says It All: No Sexual Freebies With Work
item.description: A group of women have started an online campaign against the sexual exploitation of female workers by employers after reports of a fatal rape case.
item.dc:creator: By VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: A feminist group based in Guangzhou staged an online protest against the sexual exploitation of women in the workplace. The sign reads: "My vagina does not come free with my labor."

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Turkey’s Failed Foreign Policy
item.description: The incoming prime minister thought he would have zero problems with the neighbors. Now he has several.
item.dc:creator: By AARON STEIN

item.title: Mercy-Le-Haut Journal: Exploring a World War I Battlefield 100 Years Later
item.description: A reporter’s grandfather was among the multitudes of German soldiers who stormed into France and left some 27,000 French soldiers dead 100 years ago. She returned to the scene to piece together more.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Moral Hazard of Calling ISIS a ‘Cancer’
item.description: The actions of ISIS are horrifying, but we should not cloud our judgment with moralizing language.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. BOYLE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Zoo Official by Day, Taxi Driver by Night, Court Told
item.description: Accused of corruption, a former deputy director of the Beijing Zoo stuck to his story about earning some of his extra millions of renminbi by driving a cab at night. His explanations are a long shot.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Pandas eating bamboo at the Beijing Zoo. Among the accusations against Xiao Shaoxiang are that he diverted funds intended for a refurbished panda enclosure at the zoo.

item.title: Opinion: Israel’s Move to the Right Challenges Diaspora Jews
item.description: Israel’s embrace of ever more right-wing nationalist politics has stirred a crisis among Diaspora Jews.
item.dc:creator: By ANTONY LERMAN

item.title: Russian Trucks Cross Border Without Assent of Ukraine
item.description: The first trucks from a long-stalled Russian convoy said to be carrying humanitarian aid crossed the border in eastern Ukraine, without the consent of the Ukrainian government or the Red Cross.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A Russian convoy crossed the Ukrainian border at a checkpoint in Izvaryne, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: NATO’s Second-Class Members
item.description: The absence of peacekeepers in Poland and the Baltics is a concession to Russia.
item.dc:creator: By SLAWOMIR SIERAKOWSKI

item.title: North Korea May Soon Have More Powerful Rocket
item.description: Satellite images indicate that the North is likely to have the ability to launch a rocket that can carry a heavier payload by the end of 2014, according to an American research organization.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. General Says Raiding Syria Is Key to Halting ISIS
item.description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey was circumspect in describing the sort of broad effort that would be required to roll back ISIS in Syria and Iraq.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Kurdish soldiers stood guard at the Mosul Dam after recapturing it from Sunni militants.

item.title: U.N. Raises Estimate of Dead in Syrian Conflict to 191,000
item.description: Navi Pillay, the departing United Nations high commissioner for human rights, had harsh words for the “paralysis” of the Security Council that she said contributed to the toll.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Junta Leader Is Named New Premier of Thailand
item.description: Prayuth Chan-ocha, who led the overthrow of Thailand’s government in May, was named prime minister Thursday by a rubber-stamp legislature.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha was chosen as prime minister by the National Legislative Assembly, whose members were handpicked by the junta last month.

item.title: Foley’s Parents Release Email From Captors
item.description: The parents of James Foley, the American journalist beheaded by Islamist militants, released an email from his captors in which they said he would be the first of many Americans to die.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,329 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: White House Memo: A Terrorist Horror, Then Golf: Incongruity Fuels Obama Critics
item.description: As the president returned to his vacation, a firestorm of criticism from Republicans and Democrats erupted over what many saw as a callous indifference to the slaughter of James Foley.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama on Martha’s Vineyard on Wednesday. Republicans and Democrats have said his vacation is ill timed.

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: Executions Draw Rebukes
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s judicial authorities have beheaded at least 19 convicted criminals since Aug. 4, nearly half of them for nonviolent offenses, including one for sorcery, Human Rights Watch said Thursday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Congo: Illness Kills at Least 70 People
item.description: At least 70 people have died in the northern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo from an outbreak of hemorrhagic gastroenteritis, the World Health Organization said Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: White House Memo: A Terrorist Horror, Then Golf: Incongruity Fuels Obama Critics
item.description: As the president returned to his vacation, a firestorm of criticism from Republicans and Democrats erupted over what many saw as a callous indifference to the slaughter of James Foley.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: President Obama on Martha’s Vineyard on Wednesday. Republicans and Democrats have said his vacation is ill timed.

item.title: Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu Nominated to Be Turkey’s Next Premier
item.description: Turkey’s governing party nominated Ahmet Davutoglu to succeed President-elect Recep Tayyip Erdogan as prime minister and party chairman.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Ahmet Davutoglu was chosen to succeed Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
